title: Summer on the Hudson: Amplified Sundays - Vicki Kristina Barcelona
description:
Date: July 11, 2021

Enjoy vibrantly-danceable live music accompanied by spectacular sunsets over the Hudson River. Amplified Sundays take place each Sunday in July. Music begins at 7:00 p.m.

July 11: Vicki Kristina Barcelona

Vicki Kristina Barcelona is Rachelle Garniez, Amanda Homi and Terry Radigan, a power trio of seasoned music veterans dedicated to re-imagining the songs of Tom Waits via inventive three-part harmonies and a treasure trove of instruments including banjos, bottles, squeezebox, and zills. They create a world of sound at once powerful, playful and poignant.

title: Virtual Camp Dyckman
description:
Date: July 12, 2021

The Dyckman Farmhouse Museum is excited to announce its 6th annual summer camp for youth.

From July 12 to July 16, the museum will conduct a free virtual bilingual health and wellness-focused camp. Camp attendees will focus on urban gardening, foodways, healthy cooking, and healthy movement. This camp is for children ages 8-13. There are 45 spots available and this will be virtual to keep everyone safe. For virtual attendees, children ages 8-11 must have an adult present as they may need assistance to prepare food.

Virtual attendees will need to purchase some items to participate in the cooking portion of the camp. A list will be provided after registration. Additionally, each student will receive a Grow Kit to start and sustain a mini herb garden at home, an observation educational activity to continue learning after the program finishes, which they can share with their families.

Register online

End time: 12:30 pm

Contact phone: 212.304.9422

title: Summer Apprentice Program
description:
Date: July 12, 2021

Learn a historic trade at NYC's only living history village!

Historic Richmond Town’s rich array of apprenticeships build real-world skills based upon centuries of American ingenuity. The program is a wonderful alternative to the tried and true summer camp.

Individualized sessions in the Historic Trades are conducted in small groups of less than five and accelerate learning as students work with an experienced Artisan to build their skills forging iron, shaping tin, and cooking over an open fire as they create one-of-a-kind, hand crafted items. The historic settings are fully furnished for an immersive and hands-on practice. Apprentices will visit the other trades during their week to add to the fun and the 360-degree learning.

At the end of each session, apprentices will have the ability to present their trade and lead a specialized tour of their workshop to visitors and their families.

2021 Apprentice Program Schedule:

  • Session 1 (July 5-9)
  • Session 2 (July 12-16)
  • Session 3 (July 19-23)
  • Session 4 (July 26-30)
  • Session 5 (Aug 2-6)

The Apprentice Program is divided into two areas:

Junior Apprentice Program (Ages 8-11): Experience 19th century life with daily activities led by Historical Interpreters, including nature walks, crafts, historic games, and sample each of the Summer Apprentice Trades. Make your own candles, marbled paper, and try your hand at hearth cooking, just to name a few! Participants wear period clothing and are immersed in the village site.

Pre-register for Junior Apprentice Program

Summer Apprentice Program: (Ages 12-15): Choose an apprenticeship and learn the basic skills of an early American tradesperson. Weave your own basket, cook over an open hearth, swing a hammer as an apprenticed blacksmith, or learn the fine arts of the tinsmith or carpenter. Participants work closely with highly skilled historic tradespeople, creating items using period techniques and tools. Summer Apprentice experiences inspire lifelong learning, instill a deep appreciation for history and a healthy work ethic.

Apprenticeships offered:

  • Blacksmithing
  • Carpentry
  • Tinsmithing
  • Basket Making
  • Hearth Cooking

Pre-register for the Summer Apprentie Program

Start time: 10:00 am

End time: 5:00 pm

Contact phone: (718) 351-1611

Location: Historic Richmond Town

title: Films on the Green: Elevator to the Gallows
description:
Date: July 12, 2021

Enjoy a free online screening of Elevator to the Gallows (Ascenceur pour l’échafaud) by Louis Malle as part of Films on the Green Festival!

Femme fatale Florence Carala and her lover, Julien Tavernier, plan to murder her wealthy husband, Simon–Julien’s boss–and make it look like a suicide. But Tavernier accidently gets trapped in an elevator while leaving the scene of the crime. His unfortunate oversight sets off a chain of events that seals the lovers’ fate during one restless night in Paris. Louis Malle’s feature debut with a now-legendary jazz score by Miles Davis!

#FilmsOnTheGreen | Film in French with English subtitles

Reserve Tickets Online

**The free online screening of Elevator to the Gallows will take place on the French Embassy’s virtual cinema platform on Monday July 12 at 8:30 p.m. Access to the virtual platform is based on location; people within a 30-mile radius of New York City can access the screening. The screening has a limited number of tickets available.**

title: Summer Apprentice Program
description:
Date: July 13, 2021

Learn a historic trade at NYC's only living history village!

Historic Richmond Town’s rich array of apprenticeships build real-world skills based upon centuries of American ingenuity. The program is a wonderful alternative to the tried and true summer camp.

Individualized sessions in the Historic Trades are conducted in small groups of less than five and accelerate learning as students work with an experienced Artisan to build their skills forging iron, shaping tin, and cooking over an open fire as they create one-of-a-kind, hand crafted items. The historic settings are fully furnished for an immersive and hands-on practice. Apprentices will visit the other trades during their week to add to the fun and the 360-degree learning.

At the end of each session, apprentices will have the ability to present their trade and lead a specialized tour of their workshop to visitors and their families.

2021 Apprentice Program Schedule:

  • Session 1 (July 5-9)
  • Session 2 (July 12-16)
  • Session 3 (July 19-23)
  • Session 4 (July 26-30)
  • Session 5 (Aug 2-6)

The Apprentice Program is divided into two areas:

Junior Apprentice Program (Ages 8-11): Experience 19th century life with daily activities led by Historical Interpreters, including nature walks, crafts, historic games, and sample each of the Summer Apprentice Trades. Make your own candles, marbled paper, and try your hand at hearth cooking, just to name a few! Participants wear period clothing and are immersed in the village site.

Pre-register for Junior Apprentice Program

Summer Apprentice Program: (Ages 12-15): Choose an apprenticeship and learn the basic skills of an early American tradesperson. Weave your own basket, cook over an open hearth, swing a hammer as an apprenticed blacksmith, or learn the fine arts of the tinsmith or carpenter. Participants work closely with highly skilled historic tradespeople, creating items using period techniques and tools. Summer Apprentice experiences inspire lifelong learning, instill a deep appreciation for history and a healthy work ethic.

Apprenticeships offered:

  • Blacksmithing
  • Carpentry
  • Tinsmithing
  • Basket Making
  • Hearth Cooking

Pre-register for the Summer Apprentie Program

Start time: 10:00 am

End time: 5:00 pm

title: Arts, Culture & Fun: Drawing Workshop
description:
Date: July 14, 2021

Join NYC Parks' Arts, Culture & Fun for a drawing workshop series in partnership with Seeds of the League. Artist Amberrose Venus-Gordon will lead a workshop teaching you how to draw people and nature. Please bring a photo of someone or something you would like to draw. All levels from beginners to advanced are welcome.

For your comfort, bring a mat, blanket, or folding chair to sit on. Feel free to bring your own watercolors, paper, water, and brushes. Limited supplies will be provided as well.

Seeds of the League is the Art Students League's community program.

About the artist

Amberrose Venus-Gordon currently resides in Brooklyn, New York. She is a recent graduate of Pratt Institute with a BFA in painting and minors in art history, museum and gallery practices.

Amberrose’s interest in working with children and her sensitivity to them is apparent in the way she records moments in their young lives. Her art focuses heavily on iconic symbols that are indicative of one’s childhood innocence.

Registration
Please register at cathy.mitchell@parks.nyc.gov. The class size is limited and will be on a first-come, first-serve basis on the day of the workshop.

description:

Presented by the French Consulate in New York, the French Institute Alliance Française and CAFUSA

Tickets are no longer required for free performances at SummerStage. All free performances will be open to the public, first come, first served, with limited capacity, and will continue to follow CDC recommendations. Visit here for more information.

The Bastille Day celebration kicks off with a live jazz band performing a selection of beloved French classics. The quintet is headlined by GRAMMY (R)-nominated singer Kavita Shah, and features Matt Munisteri on guitar, Matt Penman on bass, Ferenc Nemeth on drums, and Olivier Manchon on violin. Following will be a a get-up-and-dance set with movie highlights by star Joachim Garraud (frequent collaborator of David Guetta, Mylène Farmer, and Kylie Minogue). The highlight of the evening is a screening of the 2020 French comedy My Donkey, My Lover & I (Antoinette dans les Cévennes) starring the delightful Laure Calamy (Call My Agent!).

title: Sunset Yoga
description:
Date: July 14, 2021

Enjoy free yoga classes while overlooking the beautiful Hudson River and basking in the glow of the setting sun!

Arrive early and bring a towel or a yoga mat and water. Mats must be socially distanced - 6 feet apart. To measure, use your mats!

Capacity is limited due to NY Reopening restrictions. Attendance is on a “first-come, first-served” basis. Class participants must sign an NYC Parks/Fort Tryon Park Trust waiver on-site at each session.

Abby’s Lawn is slightly sloped and there are some uneven spots.

Rain or wet ground cancels the event. Please check the Fort Tryon Park Facebook Page

Certified instructor, Stacey Linden, has been teaching yoga for twenty years and it has been integral in her life — physically, mentally, and spiritually. We are happy to have her share its many facets with our park community. Stacey teaches at all levels and believes yoga should be practiced, not “perfected.” Every time we step onto our mats, we can be just a little surprised by where our bodies, minds, and breath are at that moment.

Sunset Yoga is a program presented by the Fort Tryon Park Trust that takes place from June 2 through September 1

title: Virtual Tour: An Interior Designer's Perspective: Life, Customs, and Style in Mid-19th Century New York
description:
Date: July 14, 2021

The miracle of the Merchant’s House is that it remains intact with the family’s original 19th century furniture, decorative arts, artwork, curtains, and other textiles, encapsulating a moment in time.

In this immersive video experience, you’ll follow interior designer and Merchant's House Museum volunteer docent Dennis McAvena through a unique portal of New York City design history. You’ll tour all five floors of this landmark late-Federal and Greek Revival rowhouse, exploring how the design of the period rooms reflected the family’s values and taste, and informed their use.

Following the tour, join interior designer and MHM volunteer docent Dennis McAvena for a Q&A.

Purchase tickets online

title: Summer on the Hudson: Children's Performance Series - Esther Crow
description:
Date: July 15, 2021

This children's series features music, storytelling, and theater for young audiences up to age 7. Wear sunscreen! The Children's Performance Series takes place each Thursday in July.

THURSDAY, JULY 15: Esther Crow

Born and raised in Manhattan, Esther Crow is an award-winning singer, songwriter and teacher. Esther started writing solo material for kids in 2019, and released her debut solo album, All Together Now, on June 25. The album's 10 eclectic tracks are woven together by interstitial puppet skits to create a "sonic variety show" for families. Each of her puppets have big personalities and dance moves of their own; like Bernie the Bee who loves to eat anchovies and dance to the sound of a kazoo. She weaves comedy and kindness into each show, while encouraging kids to shake instruments and move the beat of her groovy tunes.

title: Summer Apprentice Program
description:
Date: July 15, 2021

Learn a historic trade at NYC's only living history village!

Historic Richmond Town’s rich array of apprenticeships build real-world skills based upon centuries of American ingenuity. The program is a wonderful alternative to the tried and true summer camp.

Individualized sessions in the Historic Trades are conducted in small groups of less than five and accelerate learning as students work with an experienced Artisan to build their skills forging iron, shaping tin, and cooking over an open fire as they create one-of-a-kind, hand crafted items. The historic settings are fully furnished for an immersive and hands-on practice. Apprentices will visit the other trades during their week to add to the fun and the 360-degree learning.

At the end of each session, apprentices will have the ability to present their trade and lead a specialized tour of their workshop to visitors and their families.

2021 Apprentice Program Schedule:

  • Session 1 (July 5-9)
  • Session 2 (July 12-16)
  • Session 3 (July 19-23)
  • Session 4 (July 26-30)
  • Session 5 (Aug 2-6)

The Apprentice Program is divided into two areas:

Junior Apprentice Program (Ages 8-11): Experience 19th century life with daily activities led by Historical Interpreters, including nature walks, crafts, historic games, and sample each of the Summer Apprentice Trades. Make your own candles, marbled paper, and try your hand at hearth cooking, just to name a few! Participants wear period clothing and are immersed in the village site.

Pre-register for Junior Apprentice Program

Summer Apprentice Program: (Ages 12-15): Choose an apprenticeship and learn the basic skills of an early American tradesperson. Weave your own basket, cook over an open hearth, swing a hammer as an apprenticed blacksmith, or learn the fine arts of the tinsmith or carpenter. Participants work closely with highly skilled historic tradespeople, creating items using period techniques and tools. Summer Apprentice experiences inspire lifelong learning, instill a deep appreciation for history and a healthy work ethic.

Apprenticeships offered:

  • Blacksmithing
  • Carpentry
  • Tinsmithing
  • Basket Making
  • Hearth Cooking

Pre-register for the Summer Apprentie Program

Start time: 10:00 am

End time: 5:00 pm

Contact phone: (718) 351-1611

Location: Historic Richmond Town

title: Arts, Culture & Fun: Watercolor Painting Workshop
description:
Date: July 15, 2021

Join NYC Parks' Arts, Culture & Fun for a watercolor painting workshop series throughout Staten Island in partnership with Seeds of the League. Artist Kenneth Fitzpatrick will teach you how to draw and paint using nature as your inspiration. Learn about light, color, and design while making art en plein air (outside). All levels from beginners to advanced are welcome.

For your comfort, bring a mat, blanket, or folding chair to sit on. Feel free to bring your own watercolors, paper, water, and brushes. Limited supplies will be provided as well.

Seeds of the League is the Art Students League's community program.

About the artist:
Kenneth Fitzpatrick, a graduate of the High School of Art & Design, was born and raised in New York City. His awards include P.S. Art, a citywide competition for pre-K to 12, culminating in an exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and a Seeds of the League Scholarship. Ken’s work focuses on compositional storytelling using the mediums of oils, graphite, watercolors, tattoos, and digital art. His goals include finishing his degree in game development and encouraging others to pursue their art.

Registration
Please register at nicole.jensen@parks.nyc.gov. The class size is limited and will be on a first-come, first-serve basis on the day of the workshop. Families are welcome.

Please note: Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, we're offering outdoor programs with limited attendance so that you can have a safe and enjoyable time in parks. title: Summer Apprentice Program
description:
Date: July 16, 2021

Learn a historic trade at NYC's only living history village!

Historic Richmond Town’s rich array of apprenticeships build real-world skills based upon centuries of American ingenuity. The program is a wonderful alternative to the tried and true summer camp.

Individualized sessions in the Historic Trades are conducted in small groups of less than five and accelerate learning as students work with an experienced Artisan to build their skills forging iron, shaping tin, and cooking over an open fire as they create one-of-a-kind, hand crafted items. The historic settings are fully furnished for an immersive and hands-on practice. Apprentices will visit the other trades during their week to add to the fun and the 360-degree learning.

At the end of each session, apprentices will have the ability to present their trade and lead a specialized tour of their workshop to visitors and their families.

2021 Apprentice Program Schedule:

  • Session 1 (July 5-9)
  • Session 2 (July 12-16)
  • Session 3 (July 19-23)
  • Session 4 (July 26-30)
  • Session 5 (Aug 2-6)

The Apprentice Program is divided into two areas:

Junior Apprentice Program (Ages 8-11): Experience 19th century life with daily activities led by Historical Interpreters, including nature walks, crafts, historic games, and sample each of the Summer Apprentice Trades. Make your own candles, marbled paper, and try your hand at hearth cooking, just to name a few! Participants wear period clothing and are immersed in the village site.

Pre-register for Junior Apprentice Program

Summer Apprentice Program: (Ages 12-15): Choose an apprenticeship and learn the basic skills of an early American tradesperson. Weave your own basket, cook over an open hearth, swing a hammer as an apprenticed blacksmith, or learn the fine arts of the tinsmith or carpenter. Participants work closely with highly skilled historic tradespeople, creating items using period techniques and tools. Summer Apprentice experiences inspire lifelong learning, instill a deep appreciation for history and a healthy work ethic.

Apprenticeships offered:

  • Blacksmithing
  • Carpentry
  • Tinsmithing
  • Basket Making
  • Hearth Cooking

Pre-register for the Summer Apprentie Program

Start time: 10:00 am

End time: 5:00 pm

Contact phone: (718) 351-1611

title: Picnic Performances: Carnegie Hall Citywide - Spanish Harlem Orchestra
description:
Date: July 16, 2021

Spanish Harlem Orchestra, the three-time Grammy-winning Salsa and Latin Jazz band, sets the gold standard for excellence in authentic, New York style, hard core salsa.

Whether in a concert hall or at an outdoor jazz festival, there is no easing you in, they come at you full force, from start to finish. Their energy on stage and their rich sound and musical precision leave audiences mesmerized until the last note is played. With an unwavering respect for the music’s storied history, the ensemble’s thirteen world-class musicians and vocalists come together to create an unparalleled musical experience. SHO, as they are known to fans, is dedicated to the sounds of the barrio (Spanish Harlem, NYC). Their music is characterized by the raw, organic and vintage sound defined by the genre. They are on a mission to keep the musical legacy of salsa dura (hard salsa) alive and expand its audience to those who love great music, not just Latin music. Grounded in the past, while focused on the future, they strive to keep the music relevant, creating a unique and fresh approach. With six albums and five Grammy nominations, this powerhouse orchestra is aware that it is crucial to continually push themselves and raise the bar. Their latest release and 6th album, Anniversary, won the 2019 Grammy Award for Best Tropical Album.

Visit the Picnic Performances page for more information about in-park attendance.

Can't make the show in-person? Join the livestream on Facebook, Instagram, or YouTube @bryantparknyc, courtesy of Bank of America. No registration is needed for the livestream!

The first full-length animated Scooby-Doo adventure for the big screen is the never-before told stories of Scooby-Doo’s origins and the greatest mystery in the career of Mystery Inc. “SCOOB!” reveals how lifelong friends Scooby and Shaggy first met and how they joined with young detectives Fred, Velma and Daphne to form the famous Mystery Inc. title: Movies Under the Stars: Festival Friday: TIDE Film Festival
description:
Date: July 16, 2021

Join NYC Parks for Festival Friday with the TIDE Film Festival!

Celebrate independent film at this wonderful evening of short films by diverse filmmakers of color from the TIDE Film Festival at sundown. These films represent some of the most exciting new filmmakers on the indie film scene.

Adeline, The Great
Comedy, 11:30
Directed by Jessica Mendez Siqueiros
A woke boarding school student questions her commitment to activism when she finds herself with no friends, countless enemies, and facing some very serious accusations that threaten to get her expelled.

BAM & RAWLS GRAB A SLICE
Comedy Documentary, 5:30
Directed by Horatio Baltz
Bam and Rawls, two bike riders in New York City, embark on a journey to find a satisfying slice of pizza.

Home
Drama, 12:26
Directed by Adewale Olukayode
Femi, a Nigerian immigrant, must question his life values and concept of the American Dream when his brother steals a large sum of cash one night.

The Price of Cheap Rent
Comedy, 6:30
Directed by Amina Sutton & Maya Tanaka
An aspiring artist discusses the challenges of finding affordable housing and the compromises she has to make with her spooky new roommates.

Birdie
Drama, 9:58
Directed by Rachel Harrison Gordon
Birdie, a biracial girl raised by her Jewish mom, has a rare visitation day with her father while preparing for her Bat Mitzvah. Overcoming her doubts, Birdie confronts what independence means as she steps into adulthood on her own terms.

1800 - Lovable
Experimental, 1:50
Directed by Rebecca Hunt
Are you a single black woman yearning to be loved and desired? 1800 - Lovable provides the je nais se quoi that makes dreams come true, in this satirical short film shot on 16mm.

Kiss of the Rabbit God
Supernatural Thriller, 14:39
Directed by Andrew Thomas Huang
A Chinese-American restaurant worker exhausted by his job finds himself intrigued by a customer who seems to visit him in dreams.

Good Harvest
Drama, 14:55
Directed by Meyli Mars
A peek into the busy daily lives of an older Asian couple living in the suburbs of Cleveland..

Super Sonic
Romantic Drama, 15:20
Directed by Saleem Gondal
Worried that his hearing aids will fail him, Wahid must find a new language to keep his budding romance with Samar alive.

title: Gloria Gaynor / Sundae Sermon's - Dj Stormin' Norman of Disco Sequestered
description:
Date: July 17, 2021

Tickets are no longer required for free performances at SummerStage. All free performances will be open to the public, first come, first served, with limited capacity, and will continue to follow CDC recommendations. Visit here for more information.

She’s best known for her 1978 chart-topping, GRAMMY®-winning, platinum disco single “I Will Survive,” but Gloria Gaynor’s career reflects a lifelong journey through music. Gloria’s voice became ubiquitous on the radio and in discos in the 1970s, culminating in a hit single that became a global anthem for all kinds of survivals. Gaynor shifted into making faith-based songs later in life, balancing R&B and electronic dance music with gospel sensibilities. A veteran of more than a dozen studio albums, Gloria released her latest, “TESTIMONY,” in 2019 which she co-wrote and recorded in Nashville, TN with a multi-GRAMMY® Award winning team of fellow songwriters, producers, musicians, and special guest vocalists. “TESTIMONY,” received two GRAMMY® nominations for Best Roots Gospel Album and for Best Gospel Performance / Song for Gloria’s duet with Yolanda Adams on the song, “Talkin’ ‘Bout Jesus.” Gaynor took home the Best Roots Gospel GRAMMY® at the 2020 Award Ceremony. Gloria also recently launched her Merch by Amazon Shop and her very own YouTube Channel which features many of her incredible vintage concert and TV performances plus new video content

title: Greenbelt Bug Club
description:
Date: July 18, 2021

Join us, for the Greenbelt’s Summer Bug Club. Participants will learn what it takes to be an Amateur Entomologist by exploring the world of insects! The Greenbelt Bug Club is an educational mini-series that explores the anatomy, life-cycles and the natural history of BUGS through engaging conversation, presentations and live insect demos.

Ages 5+. Free.

Register on Eventbrite*

*Please register for each program date individually.

July 18th Bug Club: Welcome Junior Entomologists!

Have you ever chased butterflies, collected fireflies, observed moths, or rolled a log to see what lives beneath it? Insects are the largest group of animals on earth with nearly one million different kinds. And this first meeting will explore what makes a Bug-­A-­Bug!

July 25th Bug Club: Spiders & Their Kind

Have you ever thought about being a spider? Spiders have some amazing adaptations! Explore the life of spiders and learn how they are suited for the habitats they live in. (Live spiders and tarantulas will be in attendance.)

August 1st Bug Club: Insect Illustrations

Following in the footprints of the Staten Island Naturalist William T. Davis, we will explore the world of insects through journaling and drawing live insects both in the classroom and outside.

August 8th Bug Club: High Rock Pond Dip**

Discover the complex world of pond life and why stoneflies, mayflies, and diving beetles play critical roles in sustaining healthy aquatic ecosystems. We will record and monitor a variety of freshwater invertebrates that call the Greenbelt home.

** August 8th program will take place at High Rock Park located at 200 Nevada Avenue. All other programs will be at the Greenbelt Nature Center.

“Famously “introduced” by Eddie Palimieri in “Llegó La India via Eddie Palmieri,” Linda Viera Caballero quickly made a name for herself as La India, one of the biggest voices in salsa. But before Celia Cruz would dub her the “Princess of Salsa,” she got her start in the South Bronx, where she was a founding member of the Latin Freestyle group TKA, and cut a solo record with Freestyle legends John “Jellybean” Benitez and her husband “Little” Louie Vega. After “Llegó La India via Eddie Palmieri,” she blossomed into salsa royalty and never looked back, going on to work with Cruz and Tito Puente, and winning Best Salsa Album Latin Grammy for her album Intensamente India Con Canciones De Juan Gabriel.

title: Summer on the Hudson: Amplified Sundays - Jules and the Jinks
description:
Date: July 18, 2021

Enjoy vibrantly-danceable live music accompanied by spectacular sunsets over the Hudson River. Amplified Sundays take place each Sunday in July. Music begins at 7:00 p.m.

July 18: Jules and the Jinks

If Soul, Pop, and R&B had a threesome, their baby would sound like Jules and The Jinks, the brainchild of first-generation native New Yorkers Julissa Lopez and Erik Rosenberg. Shortly after meeting at a group vocal class in Times Square, the two began getting together regularly at Erik’s Brooklyn apartment to write music. Despite their different backgrounds (Dominican from the Bronx and Jewish from the Upper West Side) the two formed a prolific partnership. Jules and The Jinks’ work in the studio is complimented by a killer live show powered by Julissa’s earthshaking voice and mesmerizing stage presence. Songs needing to be sung, Jules and Erik raised a band with a sound that weaves Blues, Funk, and Pop with Soul. AFROPUNK described their 2015 debut EP as "effortlessly chill" and declared the record's lead single, No Compromise, "a song that deserves to be blaring from car speakers while driving through borough blocks." New music is currently in the works with releases throughout the 2020 year.

Management reserves the right to cap participation in accordance with current COVID-19 outdoor safety guidelines.

title: Summer Apprentice Program
description:
Date: July 19, 2021

Learn a historic trade at NYC's only living history village!

Historic Richmond Town’s rich array of apprenticeships build real-world skills based upon centuries of American ingenuity. The program is a wonderful alternative to the tried and true summer camp.

Individualized sessions in the Historic Trades are conducted in small groups of less than five and accelerate learning as students work with an experienced Artisan to build their skills forging iron, shaping tin, and cooking over an open fire as they create one-of-a-kind, hand crafted items. The historic settings are fully furnished for an immersive and hands-on practice. Apprentices will visit the other trades during their week to add to the fun and the 360-degree learning.

At the end of each session, apprentices will have the ability to present their trade and lead a specialized tour of their workshop to visitors and their families.

2021 Apprentice Program Schedule:

  • Session 1 (July 5-9)
  • Session 2 (July 12-16)
  • Session 3 (July 19-23)
  • Session 4 (July 26-30)
  • Session 5 (Aug 2-6)

The Apprentice Program is divided into two areas:

Junior Apprentice Program (Ages 8-11): Experience 19th century life with daily activities led by Historical Interpreters, including nature walks, crafts, historic games, and sample each of the Summer Apprentice Trades. Make your own candles, marbled paper, and try your hand at hearth cooking, just to name a few! Participants wear period clothing and are immersed in the village site.

Pre-register for Junior Apprentice Program

Summer Apprentice Program: (Ages 12-15): Choose an apprenticeship and learn the basic skills of an early American tradesperson. Weave your own basket, cook over an open hearth, swing a hammer as an apprenticed blacksmith, or learn the fine arts of the tinsmith or carpenter. title: Films on the Green: Chavela
description:
Date: July 19, 2021

Free online screening of CHAVELA by Catherine Gund and Daresha Kyi, as part of Films on the Green Festival!

Chavela is a captivating look at the unconventional life of beloved performer Chavela Vargas, whose passionate renditions of Mexican popular music and triumphant return to the stage late in life brought her international fame. In the final years of her life, Chavela comes out as lesbian and rises into her momentous third act, becoming a muse to Pedro Almodóvar, earning a Lifetime Achievement Grammy, and selling out performances at the prestigious concert halls in Paris!

#FilmsOnTheGreen | Presented in partnership with the Mexican Cultural Institute of New York and Cinema Tropical.
Film in Spanish and English with English subtitles

Get free tickets**

**The free online screening of Chavela will take place on the French Embassy’s virtual cinema platform on Monday July 19 at 8:30 p.m. Access to the virtual platform is based on location; people within a 30-mile radius of New York City can access the screening. The screening has a limited number of tickets available.**

title: Arts, Culture & Fun: Watercolor Painting Workshop
description:
Date: July 20, 2021

Join NYC Parks' Arts, Culture & Fun for a watercolor painting workshop series throughout Staten Island in partnership with Seeds of the League. Artist Kenneth Fitzpatrick will teach you how to draw and paint using nature as your inspiration. Learn about light, color, and design while making art en plein air (outside). All levels from beginners to advanced are welcome.

For your comfort, bring a mat, blanket, or folding chair to sit on. Feel free to bring your own watercolors, paper, water, and brushes. Limited supplies will be provided as well.

Seeds of the League is the Art Students League's community program.

About the artist:
Kenneth Fitzpatrick, a graduate of the High School of Art & Design, was born and raised in New York City. His awards include P.S. Art, a citywide competition for pre-K to 12, culminating in an exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and a Seeds of the League Scholarship. Ken’s work focuses on compositional storytelling using the mediums of oils, graphite, watercolors, tattoos, and digital art. His goals include finishing his degree in game development and encouraging others to pursue their art.

Registration
Please register at nicole.jensen@parks.nyc.gov. The class size is limited and will be on a first-come, first-serve basis on the day of the workshop. Families are welcome.

title: Summer Apprentice Program
description:
Date: July 20, 2021

Learn a historic trade at NYC's only living history village!

Historic Richmond Town’s rich array of apprenticeships build real-world skills based upon centuries of American ingenuity. The program is a wonderful alternative to the tried and true summer camp.

Individualized sessions in the Historic Trades are conducted in small groups of less than five and accelerate learning as students work with an experienced Artisan to build their skills forging iron, shaping tin, and cooking over an open fire as they create one-of-a-kind, hand crafted items. The historic settings are fully furnished for an immersive and hands-on practice. Apprentices will visit the other trades during their week to add to the fun and the 360-degree learning.

At the end of each session, apprentices will have the ability to present their trade and lead a specialized tour of their workshop to visitors and their families.

2021 Apprentice Program Schedule:

  • Session 1 (July 5-9)
  • Session 2 (July 12-16)
  • Session 3 (July 19-23)
  • Session 4 (July 26-30)
  • Session 5 (Aug 2-6)

The Apprentice Program is divided into two areas:

Junior Apprentice Program (Ages 8-11): Experience 19th century life with daily activities led by Historical Interpreters, including nature walks, crafts, historic games, and sample each of the Summer Apprentice Trades. Make your own candles, marbled paper, and try your hand at hearth cooking, just to name a few! Participants wear period clothing and are immersed in the village site.

Pre-register for Junior Apprentice Program

Summer Apprentice Program: (Ages 12-15): Choose an apprenticeship and learn the basic skills of an early American tradesperson. Weave your own basket, cook over an open hearth, swing a hammer as an apprenticed blacksmith, or learn the fine arts of the tinsmith or carpenter. Participants work closely with highly skilled historic tradespeople, creating items using period techniques and tools. Summer Apprentice experiences inspire lifelong learning, instill a deep appreciation for history and a healthy work ethic.

Apprenticeships offered:

  • Blacksmithing
  • Carpentry
  • Tinsmithing
  • Basket Making
  • Hearth Cooking

Pre-register for the Summer Apprentie Program

description:

Join NYC Parks' Arts, Culture & Fun for a drawing workshop series in partnership with Seeds of the League. Artist Amberrose Venus-Gordon will lead a workshop teaching you how to draw people and nature. Please bring a photo of someone or something you would like to draw. All levels from beginners to advanced are welcome.

For your comfort, bring a mat, blanket, or folding chair to sit on. Feel free to bring your own watercolors, paper, water, and brushes. Limited supplies will be provided as well.

Seeds of the League is the Art Students League's community program.

About the artist

Amberrose Venus-Gordon currently resides in Brooklyn, New York. She is a recent graduate of Pratt Institute with a BFA in painting and minors in art history, museum and gallery practices.

Amberrose’s interest in working with children and her sensitivity to them is apparent in the way she records moments in their young lives. Her art focuses heavily on iconic symbols that are indicative of one’s childhood innocence.

description:
Date: July 21, 2021

Enjoy free yoga classes while overlooking the beautiful Hudson River and basking in the glow of the setting sun!

Arrive early and bring a towel or a yoga mat and water. Mats must be socially distanced - 6 feet apart. To measure, use your mats!

Capacity is limited due to NY Reopening restrictions. Attendance is on a “first-come, first-served” basis. Class participants must sign an NYC Parks/Fort Tryon Park Trust waiver on-site at each session.

Abby’s Lawn is slightly sloped and there are some uneven spots.

Rain or wet ground cancels the event. Please check the Fort Tryon Park Facebook Page

Certified instructor, Stacey Linden, has been teaching yoga for twenty years and it has been integral in her life — physically, mentally, and spiritually. We are happy to have her share its many facets with our park community. Stacey teaches at all levels and believes yoga should be practiced, not “perfected.” Every time we step onto our mats, we can be just a little surprised by where our bodies, minds, and breath are at that moment.

Sunset Yoga is a program presented by the Fort Tryon Park Trust that takes place from June 2 through September 1

title: Films on the Green: Akounak Tedalat Taha Tazoughai
description:
Date: July 21, 2021

Free online screening of Akounak Tedalat Taha Tazoughai (Rain the Color of Blue with a Little Red in It) by Christopher Kirkley, as part of Films on the Green Festival!

Mdou Moctar is a musician trying to succeed in the raucous subculture of the Niger guitar scene. He must battle fierce competition from jealous musicians, overcome family conflicts, endure trials of the heart, and overcome his biggest rival - himself. The first ever Tuareg-language fictional film based on the legendary rock-u-drama “Purple Rain,” with stunning musical performances from real-life musician Mdou Moctar.

#FilmsOnTheGreen | Presented in partnership with the African Film Festival.
In Tamashek with English subtitles

Get free tickets**

**The free online screening of Akounak Tedalat Taha Tazoughai will take place on the French Embassy’s virtual cinema platform on Wednesday July 21 at 8:30pm. title: Summer Apprentice Program
description:
Date: July 22, 2021

Learn a historic trade at NYC's only living history village!

Historic Richmond Town’s rich array of apprenticeships build real-world skills based upon centuries of American ingenuity. The program is a wonderful alternative to the tried and true summer camp.

Individualized sessions in the Historic Trades are conducted in small groups of less than five and accelerate learning as students work with an experienced Artisan to build their skills forging iron, shaping tin, and cooking over an open fire as they create one-of-a-kind, hand crafted items. The historic settings are fully furnished for an immersive and hands-on practice. Apprentices will visit the other trades during their week to add to the fun and the 360-degree learning.

At the end of each session, apprentices will have the ability to present their trade and lead a specialized tour of their workshop to visitors and their families.

2021 Apprentice Program Schedule:

  • Session 1 (July 5-9)
  • Session 2 (July 12-16)
  • Session 3 (July 19-23)
  • Session 4 (July 26-30)
  • Session 5 (Aug 2-6)

The Apprentice Program is divided into two areas:

Junior Apprentice Program (Ages 8-11): Experience 19th century life with daily activities led by Historical Interpreters, including nature walks, crafts, historic games, and sample each of the Summer Apprentice Trades. Make your own candles, marbled paper, and try your hand at hearth cooking, just to name a few! Participants wear period clothing and are immersed in the village site.

Pre-register for Junior Apprentice Program

Summer Apprentice Program: (Ages 12-15): Choose an apprenticeship and learn the basic skills of an early American tradesperson. Weave your own basket, cook over an open hearth, swing a hammer as an apprenticed blacksmith, or learn the fine arts of the tinsmith or carpenter. Participants work closely with highly skilled historic tradespeople, creating items using period techniques and tools. Summer Apprentice experiences inspire lifelong learning, instill a deep appreciation for history and a healthy work ethic.

Apprenticeships offered:

  • Blacksmithing
  • Carpentry
  • Tinsmithing
  • Basket Making
  • Hearth Cooking

Pre-register for the Summer Apprentie Program

Start time: 10:00 am

End time: 5:00 pm

Contact phone: (718) 351-1611

Location: Historic Richmond Town

title: Arts, Culture & Fun: Watercolor Painting Workshop
description:
Date: July 22, 2021

Join NYC Parks' Arts, Culture & Fun for a watercolor painting workshop series throughout Staten Island in partnership with Seeds of the League. Artist Kenneth Fitzpatrick will teach you how to draw and paint using nature as your inspiration. Learn about light, color, and design while making art en plein air (outside). All levels from beginners to advanced are welcome.

For your comfort, bring a mat, blanket, or folding chair to sit on. Feel free to bring your own watercolors, paper, water, and brushes. Limited supplies will be provided as well.

Seeds of the League is the Art Students League's community program.

About the artist
?Kenneth Fitzpatrick, a graduate of the High School of Art & Design, was born and raised in New York City. His awards include P.S. Art, a citywide competition for pre-K to 12, culminating in an exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and a Seeds of the League Scholarship. Ken’s work focuses on compositional storytelling using the mediums of oils, graphite, watercolors, tattoos, and digital art. His goals include finishing his degree in game development and encouraging others to pursue their art.

Registration
Please register at nicole.jensen@parks.nyc.gov. The class size is limited and will be on a first-come, first-serve basis on the day of the workshop. Families are welcome.

title: Arts, Culture & Fun; Antoine Roney
description:
Date: July 22, 2021

Join us for an outdoor jazz concert with Antoine Roney.

Philadelphia-born saxophonist Antoine Roney has been a distinctive voice in jazz for over four decades. After studying with Jackie McLean at the Hartt School of Music, he worked with a long line of greats including Clifford Jordan, Donald Byrd, Rashied Ali, Arthur Taylor, Freddie Hubbard, Elvin Jones, and his late brother, Wallace Roney. An accomplished bandleader with several albums to his name, he is also the father of rising jazz star Kojo Roney.

Presented in partnership with the Jazz Foundation of America, with partial support from the National Endowment for the Arts, New York State Council on the Arts with the support of Governor Andrew M. Cuomo and the New York State Legislature, and from the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs, in partnership with the City Council.

title: Summer Apprentice Program
description:
Date: July 23, 2021

Learn a historic trade at NYC's only living history village!

Historic Richmond Town’s rich array of apprenticeships build real-world skills based upon centuries of American ingenuity. The program is a wonderful alternative to the tried and true summer camp.

Individualized sessions in the Historic Trades are conducted in small groups of less than five and accelerate learning as students work with an experienced Artisan to build their skills forging iron, shaping tin, and cooking over an open fire as they create one-of-a-kind, hand crafted items. The historic settings are fully furnished for an immersive and hands-on practice. Apprentices will visit the other trades during their week to add to the fun and the 360-degree learning.

At the end of each session, apprentices will have the ability to present their trade and lead a specialized tour of their workshop to visitors and their families.

2021 Apprentice Program Schedule:

  • Session 1 (July 5-9)
  • Session 2 (July 12-16)
  • Session 3 (July 19-23)
  • Session 4 (July 26-30)
  • Session 5 (Aug 2-6)

The Apprentice Program is divided into two areas:

Junior Apprentice Program (Ages 8-11): Experience 19th century life with daily activities led by Historical Interpreters, including nature walks, crafts, historic games, and sample each of the Summer Apprentice Trades. Make your own candles, marbled paper, and try your hand at hearth cooking, just to name a few! Participants wear period clothing and are immersed in the village site.

Pre-register for Junior Apprentice Program

Summer Apprentice Program: (Ages 12-15): Choose an apprenticeship and learn the basic skills of an early American tradesperson. Weave your own basket, cook over an open hearth, swing a hammer as an apprenticed blacksmith, or learn the fine arts of the tinsmith or carpenter. Participants work closely with highly skilled historic tradespeople, creating items using period techniques and tools. Summer Apprentice experiences inspire lifelong learning, instill a deep appreciation for history and a healthy work ethic.

Apprenticeships offered:

  • Blacksmithing
  • Carpentry
  • Tinsmithing
  • Basket Making
  • Hearth Cooking

Pre-register for the Summer Apprentie Program

Start time: 10:00 am

End time: 5:00 pm

title: Picnic Performances: Carnegie Hall Citywide - The Knights
description:
Date: July 23, 2021

The Knights are a collective of adventurous musicians dedicated to transforming the orchestral experience and eliminating barriers between audiences and music. Driven by an open-minded spirit of camaraderie and exploration, they inspire listeners with vibrant programs that encompass their roots in the classical tradition and passion for artistic discovery. The orchestra has toured and recorded with renowned soloists including Yo-Yo Ma, Dawn Upshaw, Béla Fleck, and Gil Shaham, and has performed at Carnegie Hall, Tanglewood, and the Vienna Musikverein.

The Knights evolved from late-night chamber music reading parties with friends at the home of violinist Colin Jacobsen and cellist Eric Jacobsen. The Jacobsen brothers, who are also founding members of the string quartet Brooklyn Rider, serve as artistic directors of The Knights, with Eric Jacobsen as conductor. The Knights are committed to creating unusual and adventurous partnerships across disciplines; they perform in traditional concert halls as well as parks, plazas, and bars, all in an effort to reach listeners of all backgrounds and invite them into their music-making. Since incorporating in 2007, the orchestra has toured consistently across the United States and Europe.

Visit the Picnic Performances page for more information about in-park attendance.

Can't make the show in-person? Join the livestream on Facebook, Instagram, or YouTube @bryantparknyc, courtesy of Bank of America. No registration is needed for the livestream!

title: Sun Ra Arkestra  / Sistazz of the Nitty Gritty / DJ Greg Caz
description:
Date: July 24, 2021

Tickets are no longer required for free performances at SummerStage. All free performances will be open to the public, first come, first served, with limited capacity, and will continue to follow CDC recommendations. Visit here for more information.

This performance will be livestreamed on SummerStageAnywhere.org.

The Arkestra is no stranger to SummerStage; they headlined the festival’s first-ever concert back in 1986 at the Central Park Bandshell, when they were still fronted by their eccentric and enigmatic bandleader Sun Ra. Since his death in 1993, the ensemble has been led by saxophonist Marshall Allen, and continues to carry on Sun Ra’s indomitable spirit, perpetuating his unique contributions to jazz and Afrofuturism. The Arkestra is an avant-garde history lesson in cosmic jazz, incorporating elements from throughout jazz history, including ragtime, swing, bebop, free jazz, and fusion. They’re joined by Sistazz of the Nitty Gritty (Angel Bat Dawid, Anaiet Sivad, and Brooklynn Skye Scott), an all female Chicago-based ensemble that leans on improvisation and spontaneous compositions.

Start time: 5:00 pm

End time: 8:30 pm

title: Greenbelt Bug Club
description:
Date: July 25, 2021

Join us, for the Greenbelt’s Summer Bug Club. Participants will learn what it takes to be an Amateur Entomologist by exploring the world of insects! The Greenbelt Bug Club is an educational mini-series that explores the anatomy, life-cycles and the natural history of BUGS through engaging conversation, presentations and live insect demos.

Ages 5+. Free.

Register on Eventbrite*

*Please register for each program date individually.

July 18th Bug Club: Welcome Junior Entomologists!

Have you ever chased butterflies, collected fireflies, observed moths, or rolled a log to see what lives beneath it? Insects are the largest group of animals on earth with nearly one million different kinds. And this first meeting will explore what makes a Bug-­A-­Bug!

July 25th Bug Club: Spiders & Their Kind

Have you ever thought about being a spider? Spiders have some amazing adaptations! Explore the life of spiders and learn how they are suited for the habitats they live in. (Live spiders and tarantulas will be in attendance.)

August 1st Bug Club: Insect Illustrations

Following in the footprints of the Staten Island Naturalist William T. Davis, we will explore the world of insects through journaling and drawing live insects both in the classroom and outside.

August 8th Bug Club: High Rock Pond Dip**

Discover the complex world of pond life and why stoneflies, mayflies, and diving beetles play critical roles in sustaining healthy aquatic ecosystems. We will record and monitor a variety of freshwater invertebrates that call the Greenbelt home.

** August 8th program will take place at High Rock Park located at 200 Nevada Avenue. All other programs will be at the Greenbelt Nature Center.

Start time: 10:00 am

End time: 11:00 am

Contact phone:

Location: Greenbelt Nature Center (in Blood Root Valley)

title: Birding: Shorebirds
description:
Date: July 25, 2021

New York City is home to an amazing abundance of wildlife. Our Urban Park Rangers will guide you to the best wildlife viewing spots in the urban jungle.

Shore birds such as piping plovers, oystercatchers and terns visit Rockaway Beach each year to nest and raise chicks from spring through the summer. Learn more about these and other species founds near the beach.

To enhance your experience we encourage you to bring binoculars and field guides.

title: Dance IS! featuring Artists from Rennie Harris Puremovement, Complexions Contemporary Ballet, Parsons Dance, A.I.M. by Kyle Abraham, Soles of Duende with guest artist Asha Griffith, Samantha Figgins from Alvin Ailey, Jessica Amber Pinkett, Gianna Theodore
description:
Date: July 25, 2021

Tickets are no longer required for free performances at SummerStage. All free performances will be open to the public, first come, first served, with limited capacity, and will continue to follow CDC recommendations. Visit here for more information.

This performance will be livestreamed on SummerStageAnywhere.org.

A dance showcase featuring some of the art form’s most exciting talents will feature performances by artists from Rennie Harris Puremovement, a company rooted in the foundational elements of hip-hop; Complexions Contemporary Ballet, a diverse and inclusive company focused on eliminating the boundaries of any one style, period, venue, or culture; Parsons Dance, renowned for its energized, athletic work; A.I.M. by Kyle Abraham, a company with works that entwine sensual and provocative vocabulary with a strong emphasis on sound, human behavior and all things visual; and Soles of Duende, a unique trio weaving together tap, flamenco, and kathak dance. The show will also feature a special segment artists performing to the soulful stylings of Madison McFerrin. The work was originally commissioned and produced by four/four presents for their Open Air Series. The evening will include a moment of peace and reflection by Karine Plantadit, former Alvin Ailey and Broadway Tony Award-nominated dancer, instructor, choreographer, certified yoga teacher and life coach.

Start time: 5:00 pm

End time: 8:30 pm

title: Summer on the Hudson: Amplified Sundays - Damn Tall Buildings
description:
Date: July 25, 2021

Enjoy vibrantly-danceable live music accompanied by spectacular sunsets over the Hudson River. Amplified Sundays take place each Sunday in July. Music begins at 7:00 p.m.

July 25: Damn Tall Buildings

In their early days, Damn Tall Buildings didn’t rehearse – they busked. Now, whether live or on record, the band still radiates the energy of a ragtag crew of music students playing bluegrass on the street. But anchoring that energy is their instrumental chops, their strong songwriting, and their varied influences that stretch beyond bluegrass, even beyond American roots music altogether. Whether sharing lead vocals and instrumental solos or blending their voices into loose, joyous harmony, the three members of Damn Tall Buildings (guitarist/lead vocalist Max Capistran, bassist/lead vocalist Sasha Dubyk, and fiddler/vocalist Avery Ballotta) blend elements of bluegrass, blues, roots-rock and vintage swing to create a captivating, high-energy sound.

title: Movies Under the Stars: Harriet
description:
Date: July 25, 2021

Join NYC Parks and the New York City Mayor's Office of Media and Entertainment for a free film!

This Oscar-nominated biopic follows the incredible true story of one of America's greatest heroes, Harriet Tubman. From her escape from slavery to the dangerous missions she led, setting free hundreds of slaves through the Underground Railroad. Directed by Kasi Lemmons, who also wrote the screenplay with Gregory Allen Howard. This wonderful film stars Cynthia Erivo in the title role with Leslie Odom Jr., Joe Alwyn, and Janelle Monáe in supporting roles. Rated PG-13
